analyzed: tattva darśīm bādariḥ dadarśa kāryam aprāpta pūrva tvāt aprāpta prāpaṇī gatiḥ
translated: Bādarāyaṇa, who has seen the truth, has seen that the effect is the goal, because it is not already attained. The goal is that which leads to the attainment of what is not yet attained.

analyzed: prāpayet brahma na param prāpta tvāt jagat ātmakam
translated: It would lead to Brahman, not to the supreme, because the world has Brahman as its Self.

analyzed: tattvamasi vākya artha sākṣātkārāt prāk kila jīvātma avidyā karma vāsanā ādi upādhi avacchedāt vastutas
translated: Before the realization of the meaning of the sentence That thou art, the individual soul, due to the delimitation by adjuncts like ignorance, karma, impressions, etc.,

analyzed: na avacchinnaḥ lokebhyaḥ bhinnam iva ātmānam abhimanyamānaḥ svarūpāt anyān aprāptān arciḥ ādīn lokān gatya āpnoti iti yujyate
translated: thinks of the self as really undifferentiated, but as if differentiated by the world, and as if different from its own nature, and attains by going the worlds beginning with the light, which are not different from itself. This is reasonable.

original: advaitabrahmatattvasākṣātkāravatastu vigalitanikhilaprapañcāvabhāsavibhramasya na gantavyaṃ na gatirna gamayitāra iti kiṃ kena saṃgatam /
analyzed: advaita brahma tattva sākṣātkāravataḥ tu vigalita nikhila prapañca avabhāsa vibhramasya na gantavyam na gatiḥ na gamayitāraḥ iti kim kena saṃgatam
translated: But for one who has realized the non-dual Brahman, for whom the delusion of the appearance of the entire universe has vanished, there is nothing to be gone to, no going, and no one to go. What connection can there be?

analyzed: tasmāt anidarśanam nyagrodha saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ mithas bhedāt
translated: Therefore, the example is not apt, because the conjunction and disjunction of the banyan tree, the banyan tree, the monkey, its movements, and their conjunctions and disjunctions are different from each other.

original: naca tatrāpi prāptaprāptiḥ karmajena hi vibhāgena niruddhāyāṃ pūrvaprāptāvaprāptasyaivottaraprāpterutpatteḥ /
analyzed: na ca tatra api prāpta prāptiḥ karma jena hi vibhāgena niruddhāyām pūrva prāptau aprāptasya eva uttara prāpteḥ utpatteḥ
translated: And even there, there is no attainment of what has already been attained, because the previous attainment, which has been stopped by the disjunction born of karma, has ceased, and the subsequent attainment arises only of what has not been attained.

original: etadapi vastuto vicārasahatayā sarvamanirvacanīyaṃ vijṛmbhitamavidyāyāḥ samutpannādvaitatattvasākṣātkāro na vidvānabhimanyate /
analyzed: etat api vastutas vicāra saha tayā sarvam anirvacanīyam vijṛmbhitam avidyāyāḥ samutpanna advaita tattva sākṣātkāraḥ na vidvān abhimanyate
translated: This too, in reality, is all the manifestation of ignorance, which is not tenable under scrutiny. One who has realized the non-dual truth does not think so.

analyzed: viduṣaḥ pi dehapātāt pūrvam sthita prajñasya yathā ābhāsa mātreṇa sāṃsārika dharma anuvṛttiḥ abhyupeyate evam āliṅga śarīrapātāt viduṣaḥ tad dharma anuvṛttiḥ
translated: Just as it is admitted that the worldly attributes continue in the case of the man of steady wisdom, even after his death, by mere appearance, so also the worldly attributes continue in the case of the man of knowledge, even after the death of the body of the intermediate state.

analyzed: tathā ca aprāpta prāpteḥ gati upapattiḥ tad deśa prāptau ca liṅga deha nivṛtteḥ muktiḥ śruti prāmāṇyāt iti ced na
translated: And thus, there is the possibility of going to the place not yet reached, and when that place is reached, there is liberation due to the cessation of the body of the intermediate state, by the authority of the scriptures. If this is argued, it is not so.

original: paravidyāvata utkrāntipratiṣedhāt 'brahmaiva sanbrahmāpyeti na tasmātprāṇā utkrāmanti atraiva samavanīyante'iti /🔽yathā vidyābrahmaprāptyoḥ samānakālatā śrūyate 'brahma veda brahmaiva bhavati' 'ānandaṃ🔽brahmaṇo vidvānna bibheti' 'tadātmānameva vedāhaṃ brahmāsmīti tatsarvamabhavat' 'tatra
analyzed: para vidyāvataḥ utkrānti pratiṣedhāt brahma eva san brahma apyeti na tasmāt prāṇāḥ utkrāmanti atra eva samavanīyante iti  yathā vidyā brahma prāptyoḥ samāna kāla tā śrūyate brahma veda brahmā eva bhavati ānandam  brahmaṇaḥ vidvān na bibheti tadā ātmānam eva veda aham brahma asmi iti tat sarvam abhavat tatra
translated: Because there is a prohibition of departure for one who has attained the supreme knowledge: Brahman alone, having become Brahman, goes to Brahman. The vital breaths do not depart from here. They are merged right here.

original: ko mohaḥ kaḥ śoka ekatvamanupaśyataḥ'iti paurvāparyāśravaṇāt paravidyāvato muktiṃ🔽prati nopāyāntarāpekṣeti lakṣyate 'bhisaṃdhiḥ śruteḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ mohaḥ kaḥ śokaḥ eka tvam anupaśyataḥ iti paurvāparya a śravaṇāt para vidyāvataḥ muktim  prati na upāya antara apekṣā iti lakṣyate bhisaṃdhiḥ śruteḥ
translated: Just as the attainment of knowledge and Brahman is heard to be simultaneous: One who knows Brahman becomes Brahman itself. One who knows the bliss of Brahman does not fear. He knows himself thus: 'I am Brahman.' All this became (his). There, what delusion, what grief, for one who sees unity? Because the sequence is not heard, it is understood that the intention of the scripture is that for one who has attained the supreme knowledge, there is no need for any other means for liberation.

analyzed: upapannam ca etat
translated: And this is reasonable.

original: na khalu brahmaivedaṃ viśvamahaṃ brahmāsmīti paribhāvanābhuvā jīvātmano brahmabhāvasākṣātkāreṇonmūlitāyāmanavayavenāvidyāyāmasti
analyzed: na khalu brahma eva idam viśvam aham brahma asmi iti paribhāvanā bhuvā jīvātmanaḥ brahma bhāva sākṣātkāreṇa unmūlitāyām anavayavena avidyāyām asti
translated: When ignorance, which is the root of the distinction between the knower and the known, is uprooted by the direct realization of the identity of the individual self with Brahman, through the contemplation that 'this universe is verily Brahman, I am Brahman', then

analyzed: gantavya gantṛ vibhāgaḥ viduṣaḥ tad abhāve katham ayam arciḥ ādi mārge pravarteta
translated: how can there be the distinction between the one who goes and the place to be gone to for the knower? In the absence of that, how can he proceed along the path beginning with light?

analyzed: na ca chāyā mātreṇa api sāṃsārika dharma anuvṛttiḥ tatra pravṛtti aṅgam yādṛcchika pravṛtteḥ
translated: And the continuation of worldly duties even by mere shadow is not a means of engaging in that, because of accidental engagement.

original: śraddhāvihīnasya dṛṣṭārthāni karmāṇi phalanti na phalanti ca /
analyzed: śraddhā vihīnasya dṛṣṭa arthāni karmāṇi phalanti na phalanti ca
translated: For one devoid of faith, even the seen rites bear fruit and do not bear fruit.

original: adṛṣṭārthānāṃ tu phale kā kathetyuktaṃ prathamasūtre /
analyzed: adṛṣṭa arthānām tu phale kā kathā iti uktam prathama sūtre
translated: But what to speak of the unseen rites? This has been said in the first aphorism.

original: na cārcirādimārgabhāvanāyāḥ parabrahmaprāptyarthamaviduṣaḥ pratyupadeśastathā ca karmāntareṣviva nityādiṣu tatrāpi syāttasya pravṛttirapi sāmpratam
analyzed: na ca arciḥ ādi mārga bhāvanāyāḥ para brahma prāpti artham aviduṣaḥ pratyupadeśaḥ tathā ca karma antareṣu iva nitya ādiṣu tatra api syāt tasya pravṛttiḥ api sāmpratam
translated: And it is not proper that the ignorant should be instructed in the meditation on the path beginning with light for the attainment of the supreme Brahman, and that he should engage in that just as in other rites like the obligatory ones.

analyzed: vikalpa asaha tvāt
translated: Because it cannot bear the alternatives.

analyzed: kim iyam para vidyā anapekṣā para brahma prāpti sādhanam tad apekṣā vā
translated: Is this a means of attaining the supreme Brahman without depending on the knowledge of the supreme, or with that dependence?

original: na tāvadanapekṣā 'tameva viditvātimṛtyumeti nānyaḥ panthā vidyate 'yanāya'iti parabrahmavijñānādanyasyādhvanaḥ sākṣātpratiṣedhāt /
analyzed: na tāvat anapekṣā tam eva viditvā atimṛtyum eti na anyaḥ panthāḥ vidyate yanāya eti para brahma vijñānāt anyasya adhvanaḥ sākṣāt pratiṣedhāt
translated: Nor can it be said that the meditation on the path is independent of the knowledge of Brahman, because the direct denial of any other path than the knowledge of the highest Brahman is found in the passage, By knowing Him one passes over death; there is no other path to go to , .

original: paravidyāpekṣatve tu mārgabhāvanāyāḥ kimiyaṃ vidyākārye mārgabhāvanā sāhāyakamācaratyatha vidyotpāde /
analyzed: para vidyā apekṣa tve tu mārga bhāvanāyāḥ kim iyam vidyā kārye mārga bhāvanā sāhāyakam ācarati atha vidyā utpāde
translated: If, on the other hand, the meditation on the path depends on the knowledge of the highest Brahman, does it then assist the effect of the knowledge, or the origination of the knowledge?

original: na tāvadvidyākārye tayā saha tasyā dvaitādvaitagocaratayā mitho virodhena sahāsaṃbhavāt /🔽nāpi yajñādivadvidyotpāde sākṣātbrahmaprāptyupāyatvaśravaṇādetānbrahma gamayatīti /
analyzed: na tāvat vidyā kārye tayā saha tasyāḥ dvaita advaita gocara tayā mithas virodhena saha asaṃbhavāt  nā api yajña ādi vat vidyā utpāde sākṣāt brahma prāpti upāya tva śravaṇāt etān brahma gamayati iti
translated: It cannot assist the effect of the knowledge, because the meditation on the path has for its object the duality of the knower and the known, and thus is mutually contradictory to the knowledge which has for its object the nonduality of the Self; and because the two cannot coexist

analyzed: yajña ādeḥ tu vividiṣā saṃyogena śravaṇāt vidyā utpāda aṅga tvam
translated: Nor can it be said that the meditation on the path assists the origination of the knowledge of Brahman, like the sacrificial action, &c, because the origination of the knowledge of Brahman is declared to be the direct means of attaining Brahman, and because the meditation on the path is not mentioned in the passage, He sends them to Brahman, as the sacrificial action, &c, are mentioned in the passage, He sends them to the world of Agni, &c🔽But the sacrificial action, &c, are mentioned in the passage, He who knows Brahman reaches the end of all desires, as means of the origination of the knowledge of Brahman, because they are mentioned in connexion with the desire to know Brahman

analyzed: tasmāt upanyasta bahu śruti anurodhāt upapatteḥ ca saṃbhavat mukhya vṛttiḥ brahma sāmīpyāt aparabrahmaṇi lakṣaṇayā netavyaḥ
translated: Therefore the word Brahman, which cannot be taken in its primary sense, must be explained by means of the secondary meaning of the word, on the ground of the proximity of the highest Brahman, in accordance with the many scriptural passages quoted above and with reason

original: tathāca lokeṣviti bahuvacanopapatteḥ kāryabrahmalokasya /🔽parasya tvanavayavatayā taddvāreṇāpyanupapatteḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca lokeṣu iti bahuvacana upapatteḥ kārya brahma lokasya 🔽parasya tu anavayavatayā tad dvāreṇa api anupapatteḥ
translated: And thus the plural number in the worlds is accounted for, because the world of the effect is manifold🔽But the highest Brahman is not manifold, and therefore cannot be the meaning of the word

original: lokatvaṃ celāvṛttādivatsanniveśaviśeṣavati bhogabhūmau nirūḍhaṃ na kathañcidyogena prakāśe vyākhyātaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: loka tvam cela āvṛtta ādi vat sanniveśa viśeṣavati bhogabhūmau nirūḍham na kathañcid yogena prakāśe vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: And the state of being an object of enjoyment is well-established in the sphere of enjoyment which has a special arrangement like a cloth, etc., and is not explained in any way as light by Yoga.

analyzed: tasmāt sādhu darśī sa bhagavān bādariḥ asādhu darśī jaiminiḥ iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is established that the revered Badari is a seer of the good, and Jaimini is a seer of the bad.

original: aprāmāṇikānāṃ bahupralāpāḥ sarvagatasya dravyasya guṇāḥ sarvagatā eva caitanyānandādayaśca
analyzed: a prāmāṇikānām bahu pralāpāḥ sarva gatasya dravyasya guṇāḥ sarva gatāḥ eva caitanya ānanda ādayaḥ ca
translated: The many idle speculations of those who are not authoritative, such as the qualities of the all-pervading substance are all-pervading, and consciousness, bliss, etc.

original: guṇinaḥ paramātmano bhedābhedavanto guṇā ityādayo dūṣaṇāyānubhāṣyamāṇā apyaprāmāṇikatvamāvahantyasmākamityupekṣitāḥ /
analyzed: guṇinaḥ paramātmanaḥ bheda abhedavantaḥ guṇāḥ ityādayaḥ dūṣaṇāya anubhāṣyamāṇāḥ api aprāmāṇika tvam āvahanti asmākam iti upekṣitāḥ
translated: are qualities of the supreme self which is the possessor, and are different and non-different, even when repeated for refutation, only bring about lack of authority for us, so they are ignored.

original: granthayojanā tupratyagātmatvācca gantṝṇāṃ pratiprati añcati gacchatīti pratyak pratibhāvavṛtti brahma tadātmatvādgantṝṇāṃ jīvātmanāmiti /
analyzed: grantha yojanā tu pratyak ātma tvāt ca gantṝṇām prati prati añcati gacchati iti pratyak pratibhāva vṛtti brahma tad ātma tvāt gantṝṇām jīva ātmanām iti
translated: As for the arrangement of the text, it is said that Brahman, which moves towards each individual, goes towards each individual, is the inner controller, and because of being the self of the individual selves that go.

analyzed: gauṇī tu anyatra iti
translated: But elsewhere it is secondary.

analyzed: yaugikī api hi yoga guṇa apekṣayā gauṇī eva
translated: Even the etymological one is secondary in relation to the qualities of yoga.

analyzed: viśuddha upādhi saṃbandham iti
translated: It is said to be the relation with a pure limiting adjunct.

analyzed: manaḥ maya tva ādayaḥ kalpanāḥ kāryāḥ
translated: The conceptions such as being made of mind should be performed.

analyzed: kārya tvāt aviśuddhāḥ api śreyaḥ hetu tvāt viśuddhāḥ
translated: Although impure because of being an effect, they are pure because they are the cause of the highest good.

analyzed: pratisaṃcaraḥ mahāpralayaḥ pratipatti abhisaṃdhiḥ pratipattiḥ gatiḥ
translated: Prati-samcara is the great dissolution. Pratipatti-abhisandhi is the intention of practice. Pratipatti is the course, because the meaning of pada is course.

analyzed: abhisaṃdhiḥ tātparyam
translated: Abhisandhi is the purport.

analyzed: yasya brahmaṇaḥ nāma abhidhānam yaśaḥ iti
translated: The name of that Brahman is Yas.

analyzed: pūrva vākya vicchedena iti
translated: By the interruption of the previous sentence.

analyzed: śruti vākye balīyasī prakaraṇāt
translated: In the case of the Vedic text and sentence, it is stronger than the context.

analyzed: sa guṇe ca brahmaṇi iti
translated: And even in Brahman with qualities.

analyzed: praśaṃsā artham iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is for the purpose of praise.

analyzed: codayati nanu gatasya api pāramārthikī gantavya tā deśa antara viśiṣṭasya iti
translated: He objects: Even for one who has gone, there is an ultimate destination characterized by a different place.

analyzed: nyagrodha vānara dṛṣṭāntaḥ upapāditaḥ
translated: The example of the banyan tree and the monkey is explained.

analyzed: pariharati na
translated: He replies: No.

analyzed: pratiṣiddha sarva viśeṣa tvāt brahmaṇaḥ iti
translated: Because Brahman has all distinctions refuted.

analyzed: ayam abhisaṃdhiḥ yathā tathā nyagrodha avayavī pariṇāmavān upajana apāya dharmabhiḥ karma jaiḥ
translated: This is the intention: The banyan tree as a whole, which is subject to transformation, is connected with the qualities of increase and decrease, which arise from karma,

original: saṃyogavibhāgaiḥ saṃyujyatāmayaṃ punaḥ paramātmā nirastanikhilabhedaprapañcaḥ kūṭasthanityo
analyzed: saṃyoga vibhāgaiḥ saṃyujyatām ayam punar paramātmā nirasta nikhila bheda prapañcaḥ kūṭastha nityaḥ
translated: with conjunctions and disjunctions. But this supreme self, from whom the entire manifold of distinctions has been removed, is eternally unchanging,

analyzed: na nyagrodha vat saṃyoga vibhāga bhāj bhavitum arhati
translated: and does not deserve to be subject to conjunction and disjunction like the banyan tree.

analyzed: kālpanika saṃyoga vibhāgaḥ tu kālpanikasya eva kārya brahmalokasya upapadyate na parasya
translated: But the conjunction and disjunction that are assumed are possible only for the assumed effect, the world of Brahman, not for the real one.

analyzed: śaṅkate jagat utpatti sthiti pralaya hetutva śruteḥ iti  na hi utpatti ādi hetu bhāvaḥ pariṇāminaḥ saṃbhavati tasmāt pariṇāmi iti
translated: He raises an objection: Because of the Vedic declaration of Brahman as the cause of the origin, sustentation, and dissolution of the world.🔽For the state of being the cause of origin, etc., is not possible for what is unchanging. Therefore it must be changing.

analyzed: tathā ca bhāvikam asya upapadyate gantavya tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus its being an object of attainment becomes real. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nirākaroti na
translated: He refutes this, saying: No.

analyzed: viśeṣa nirākaraṇa śrutinām iti
translated: Because of the Vedic declaration of the denial of distinctions.

analyzed: viśeṣa nirākaraṇam samasta śoka ādi duḥkha śamanatayā puruṣa artha phala vat
translated: The denial of distinctions, being conducive to the cessation of all grief and other sorrows, is fruitful for man.

analyzed: aphalam tu utpatti ādi vidhānam
translated: But the injunction of origination, etc., is fruitless.

analyzed: tasmāt phalavataḥ saṃnidhau āmnāyamānam tad artham eva ucyate iti upapattiḥ
translated: Therefore, it is reasonable that what is mentioned in the proximity of what is fruitful is stated only for that purpose.

analyzed: tat vijijñāsasva iti ca śrutiḥ
translated: And the Vedic text says: You should seek to know that.

analyzed: tasmāt śruti upapattibhyām nirasta samasta viśeṣa brahma pratipādana paraḥ yama āmnāyaḥ na tu utpatti ādi pratipādana paraḥ
translated: Therefore, this scriptural text, which is supported by reasoning, is devoted to teaching Brahman, which is devoid of all distinctions, and is not devoted to teaching origination, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt na gatiḥ tāttvikī
translated: Therefore, the attainment is not real.

original: api ceyaṃ gatirna vicāraṃ sahata ityāhagatikalpanāyāṃ ceti /
analyzed: api ca iyam gatiḥ na vicāram sahate iti āha gati kalpanāyām ca iti
translated: Moreover, this attainment cannot withstand scrutiny. He says: And in the assumption of attainment,

analyzed: anya ananya tva īśrayau avayava vikāra pakṣau
translated: The two alternatives of the parts and modification are based on identity and difference.

analyzed: anyaḥ vā atyantam
translated: The other is absolutely.

original: atha kasmādātyantikamananyatvaṃ na kalpyata ityata āhaatyantatādātmya iti /
analyzed: atha kasmāt ātyantikam ananyatvam na kalpyate iti atas āha atyanta tādātmye iti
translated: Now, why is absolute identity not assumed? To this he says: In absolute identity, there is no modification.

original: mṛdātmatayā hi svabhāvena ghaṭādayo bhāvāstadvikārā vyāptāḥ /
analyzed: mṛd ātma tayā hi svabhāvena ghaṭa ādayaḥ bhāvāḥ tad vikārāḥ vyāptāḥ
translated: For, by the nature of being clay, things like pots are pervaded by its modifications.

original: tadabhāve na bhavanti śiṃśapeva vṛkṣatvābhāva iti /
analyzed: tad abhāve na bhavanti śiṃśapā iva vṛkṣa tva abhāve iti
translated: They do not exist without it, like a śiṃśapā tree without the nature of a tree.

original: vikārāvayavapakṣayośca tadvataḥ saha vikārāvayavaiḥsthiratvādacalatvādbrahmaṇaḥ saṃsāralakṣaṇaṃ gamanaṃ vikārāvayavayeranupapannam /
analyzed: vikāra avayava pakṣayoḥ ca tadvataḥ saha vikāra avayavaiḥ sthira tvāt acala tvāt brahmaṇaḥ saṃsāra lakṣaṇam gamanam vikāra avayavayeḥ anupapannam
translated: And in the case of the parts and modification, due to the immobility or unchangeability of Brahman along with its parts and modifications, the movement characterized by transmigration is not possible for Brahman.

analyzed: nahi sthira ātmakam asthiram bhavati
translated: For what has a stable nature does not become unstable.

original: anyānanyatve api caikasya virodhādasaṃbhavantī iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: anya ananyatve api ca ekasya virodhāt asaṃbhavantī iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And in the case of identity and difference, since that is contradictory for one thing, it is impossible. This is the meaning.

analyzed: atha anyaḥ eva jīvaḥ brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Now, if the individual soul is different from Brahman,

original: tathāca brahmaṇyasaṃsaratyapi jīvasya saṃsāraḥ kalpyata iti /
analyzed: tathā ca brahmaṇi a saṃsarati api jīvasya saṃsāraḥ kalpyate iti
translated: and thus the transmigration of the individual soul is imagined even when Brahman does not transmigrate.

analyzed: etat vikalpya dūṣayati saḥ ṇuḥ iti
translated: Having considered this, he refutes it: That atom, etc.

analyzed: madhyama parimāṇa tve iti
translated: In the case of having medium size,

analyzed: madhyama parimāṇānām ghaṭa ādīnām anitya tva darśanāt na
translated: because things with medium size such as pots are seen to be impermanent, it is not so.

analyzed: mukhya ekatva iti
translated: In the case of primary oneness, etc.

analyzed: bheda abhedayoḥ virodhinoḥ ekatra asaṃbhavāt buddhi vyapadeśa bhedāt artha bhedaḥ
translated: Because of the impossibility of the contradictory attributes of difference and non-difference in one thing, there is difference of things on account of the difference of cognition and verbal expression.

analyzed: ayuta siddhatayā upacāreṇa abhinnam ucyate iti amukhyam asya eka tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: It is said to be non-different by the figurative use of the term in the sense of non-different-from, and so its oneness is not primary. This is the meaning.

original: apica jīvānāṃ brahmāvayavatvapariṇāmātyantabhedapakṣeṣu tāttvikī saṃsāriteti muktau svabhāvahānājjīvānāṃ vināśaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: apica jīvānām brahma avayava tva pariṇāma atyanta bheda pakṣeṣu tāttvikī saṃsāritā iti muktau svabhāva hānāt jīvānām vināśa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Moreover, in the views that the individual souls are parts, modifications, or absolutely different from Brahman, the transmigratory state is real. Therefore, in liberation, there would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of the individual souls due to the loss of their nature.

original: brahmavivartatve tu brahmaivaiṣāṃ svabhāvaḥ pratibimbānāmiva bimbaṃ taccāvināśīti na jīvavināśa ityāhasarveṣveteṣviti /
analyzed: brahma vivarta tve tu brahma eva eṣām svabhāvaḥ pratibimbānām iva bimbam tat ca avināśi iti na jīva vināśaḥ iti āha sarveṣu eteṣu iti
translated: But if they are modifications of Brahman, then Brahman itself is their nature, just as the mirror is the nature of the reflections, and that is imperishable. Therefore, there is no destruction of the individual souls. He says this in the verse In all these views...

analyzed: mata antaram upanyasyati dūṣayitum yat tu kaiścid jalpyate vinā eva brahma jñānam nitya naimittikāni iti
translated: In order to present and refute another view, he says: But some argue that without the knowledge of Brahman, the obligatory and occasional rites alone lead to liberation.

original: yathā hi kaphanimitto jvara upāttasya kaphasya viśeṣaṇādibhiḥ prakṣaye kaphāntarotpattinimittadadhyādivarjane praśānto 'pi na punarbhavati
analyzed: yathā hi kapha nimittaḥ jvaraḥ upāttasya kaphasya viśeṣaṇa ādibhiḥ prakṣaye kapha antara utpatti nimitta dadhi ādi varjane na punar bhavati
translated: Just as a fever caused by phlegm ceases when the phlegm that caused it is eliminated by specific treatments, and does not recur even when curd and other causative factors are avoided,

original: evaṃ karmanimitto bandha upāttānāṃ karmaṇāmupabhogātprakṣaye praśāmyati /
analyzed: evam karma nimittaḥ bandhaḥ upāttānām karmaṇām upabhogāt prakṣaye praśāmyati
translated: in the same way, bondage caused by karma ceases when the karma that caused it is exhausted by being experienced.

original: karmāntarāmaṇāṃ ca bandhahetūnāmananuṣṭhānātkāraṇābhāve kāryānupapatterbandhābhāvātsvabhāvasiddho mokṣa ārogyamiva /🔽upāttaduritanibarhaṇāya ca nityanaimittikakarmānuṣṭhānādduritanimittapratyavāyo na bhavati /
analyzed: ca bandha hetūnām ananuṣṭhānāt kāraṇa abhāve kārya anupapatteḥ bandha abhāvāt svabhāva siddhaḥ mokṣaḥ ārogyam iva  upātta durita nibarhaṇāya ca nitya naimittika karma anuṣṭhānāt durita nimitta pratyavāyaḥ na bhavati
translated: And because of the non-performance of the causes of bondage, the other actions, there is no bondage due to the non-existence of the effect in the absence of the cause. Liberation is established by nature, like health.🔽And in order to destroy the previously accumulated evil, by the performance of obligatory and occasional duties, there is no adverse result caused by evil.

analyzed: pratyavāya anutpattau ca svastha svāntaḥ na niṣiddhāni ācaret iti
translated: And in the absence of the arising of adverse results, one whose mind is at ease should not do what is prohibited.

analyzed: tat etat dūṣayati tat asat
translated: This is refuted by him (Kumārila). That is not so.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt iti
translated: Because there is no evidence.

analyzed: śāstram khalu asmin pramāṇam tat ca mokṣamāṇasya ātma jñānam eva upadiśati na tu uktam ācāram
translated: The scripture is indeed the evidence in this matter, and that teaches only the knowledge of the self for one who desires liberation, not the conduct mentioned.

original: na cātropapattiḥ prabhavati saṃsārasyānāditayā karmāśayasyāpyasaṃkhyeyasyāniyatavipākakālasya bhogenocchettumaśakyatvādityāhana caitattarkayitumapīti🔽codayatisyādetaditi /
analyzed: na ca atra upapattiḥ prabhavati saṃsārasya anādi tayā karma āśayasya api asaṃkhyeyasya aniyata vipāka kālasya bhogena ucchettum aśakya tvāt iti āha na ca etat tarkayitum api iti  codayati syāt etat iti
translated: And here reasoning is not possible, because of the beginninglessness of transmigration, and because of the impossibility of destroying by experience the immeasurable store of karma, of which the time of fruition is uncertain. Therefore he says: And this cannot even be reasoned about.🔽He objects: This may be so.

analyzed: nityā iti
translated: Obligatory and occasional duties.

analyzed: pariharati tat na virodha abhāvāt iti
translated: He replies: That is not so, because there is no contradiction.

original: yadi hi nityanaimittikāni karmāṇi sukṛtamapi duṣkṛtamiva nirvaheyustataḥ kāmyakarmopadeśā dattajalāñjalayaḥ prasajyeran /
analyzed: yadi hi nitya naimittikāni karmāṇi sukṛtam api duṣkṛtam iva nirvaheyuḥ tatas kāmya karma upadeśāḥ datta jala añjalayaḥ prasajyeran
translated: For if the obligatory and occasional rites would accomplish good as well as bad, then the teachings of optional rites would be like water offered to the dead.

original: nahyasti kaściccāturvarṇye cāturāśramye vā yo na nityanaimittikāni karmāṇi karoti /
analyzed: na hi asti kaścid cāturvarṇye cāturāśramye vā yaḥ na nitya naimittikāni karmāṇi karoti
translated: For there is no one in the four castes or four life stages who does not perform the obligatory and occasional rites.

analyzed: tasmāt na eṣām sukṛta virodhi tā iti
translated: Therefore, they do not contradict good deeds.

analyzed: abhyuccaya mātram āha na ca nitya naimittika anuṣṭhānāt iti
translated: He says and by performing the obligatory and occasional rites only as an addition.

analyzed: na ca asati samyak darśane iti
translated: And without right knowledge.

original: samyagdarśī hi viraktaḥ kāmyaniṣiddhe varjayannapi pramādādupanipatite tenaivasamyagdarśanena kṣapayati /
analyzed: samyak darśī hi viraktaḥ kāmya niṣiddhe varjayan api pramādāt upanipatite tena eva samyak darśanena kṣapayati
translated: For one with right knowledge, being detached, even though avoiding the optional and prohibited, still if they occur due to negligence, he destroys them by that same right knowledge.

original: jñānaparipāke ca na karotyeva ajñastu nipuṇo 'pi pramādātkaroti /
analyzed: jñāna paripāke ca na karoti eva ajñaḥ tu pramādāt karoti
translated: And when knowledge is matured, he does not commit them. But one without knowledge, even if skillful, commits them due to negligence.

original: kṛte ca na kṣapayituṃ kṣamata iti viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: kṛte ca na kṣapayitum kṣamate iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: And once committed, he is not able to destroy them. This is the difference.

analyzed: na ca an abhyupagamyamāne jñāna gamye brahma ātma tve iti
translated: And if the Brahman-Self, which is to be known through knowledge, is not accepted.

original: kartṛtvabhoktṛtve samākṣiptakriyābhoge te cedātmanaḥ svabhāvāvadhārite na tvāropite tato na śakyāvapanetum /
analyzed: kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tve samākṣipta kriyā bhoge te ced ātmanaḥ svabhāva avadhārite na tu āropite tatas na śakyau apanetum
translated: If agency and enjoyment, which include action and experience, are determined as the nature of the Self, not superimposed, then they cannot be removed.

analyzed: nahi svabhāvāt bhāvaḥ varopayitum śakyaḥ bhāvasya vināśa prasaṅgāt
translated: For an existent cannot be removed from its own nature, because that would entail the destruction of the existent.

analyzed: na ca bhogaḥ pi sat svabhāvaḥ śakyaḥ satkartum
translated: And enjoyment also, which has the nature of existence, cannot be made non-existent.

original: no khalu nīlamanīlaṃ śakyaṃ śakreṇāpi kartuṃ tadidamuktaṃsvabhāvasyāparihāryatvāditi /🔽samāropitasya tvanirvacanīyasya tatsvabhāvasya śakyastattvajñānenāvaropaḥ kartuṃ sarpasyeva rajjutattvajñāneneti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: no khalu nīlam anīlam śakyam śakreṇa api kartum tat idam uktam svabhāvasya a parihārya tvāt iti  samāropitasya tu anirvacanīyasya tad svabhāvasya śakyaḥ tattva jñānena avaropaḥ kartum sarpasya iva rajju tattva jñānena iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Indeed, blue cannot be made non-blue even by Indra. This is what is said: Because the own nature cannot be avoided.🔽But the superimposed, which has that nature that cannot be expressed, can be removed by the knowledge of reality, like a snake by the knowledge of reality of a rope. This is the meaning.

analyzed: bhāvam imam avidvān paricodayati syāt etat
translated: Not knowing this fact, the opponent objects: This may be so.

analyzed: kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tva kāryam iti
translated: The effect of being an agent and an experiencer.

analyzed: aprakāśita bhāvaḥ yathā uktam eva samādhatte etat ca na iti
translated: He answers as stated, And that is not so,

original: kartṛtvabhoktṛtvayornimittasaṃbandhasya ca śaktidvāreṇa nityatvādbhaviṣyati kadācideṣāṃ samudācāro yataḥ sukhaduḥkhe bhojyete iti saṃbhāvanātaḥ
analyzed: kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tvayoḥ nimitta saṃbandhasya ca śakti dvāreṇa nitya tvāt bhaviṣyati kadācid eṣām samudācāraḥ yatas sukha duḥkhe bhojyete iti saṃbhāvanātaḥ
translated: because the capacity of being an agent and an experiencer and the causal relation are eternal through the door of potentiality, the manifestation of these will occur at some time, from which pleasure and pain are experienced. Thus, the possibility

analyzed: kutas kaivalya niścayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: is from where there is certainty of isolation? This is the meaning.

analyzed: bhūyas nirastam api mati draḍhimne punar upanyasya dūṣayati parasmāt ananyatve pi iti
translated: Although refuted many times, it is presented again for the sake of strengthening the understanding and is refuted: Even if it is not different from the other...

analyzed: śeṣam atirohita artham  start
translated: The rest of the passage is of self-evident meaning.

analyzed: viśeṣita tvāt ca  sāmīpyāt tu tad vyapadeśaḥ
translated: And because it is qualified.🔽But it is designated as that on account of proximity.

analyzed: kārya atyaye tad adhyakṣeṇa saha atas param abhidhānāt
translated: After the completion of the effect, it goes beyond with that as its object, because it is mentioned subsequently.

analyzed: smṛteḥ ca
translated: And because of Smṛti.

analyzed: param jaiminiḥ mukhya tvāt
translated: Jaimini thinks that the highest Brahman is the object of upāsanā, because it is the chief one.

analyzed: darśanāt ca
translated: And because it is seen.

analyzed: na ca kārye pratipatti abhisaṃdhiḥ  start
translated: And there is no intention to apprehend the effect.

original: apratīkālambanān nayatīti bādarāyaṇa ubhayathā ca doṣāt tatkratuś ca / / / /🔽abrahmakratavo yānti yathā pañcāgnividyayā /
analyzed: a pratīka ālambanāt nayati iti bādarāyaṇaḥ ubhayathā ca doṣāt tad kratuḥ ca  a brahma kratavaḥ yānti yathā pañcāgni vidyayā
translated: Because it leads to the object of perception immediately, says Bādarāyaṇa; and because there is fault on both sides, the meditation on that is.🔽Those who are not intent on Brahman go by the path of light etc.,

analyzed: brahma lokam prayāsyanti pratīka upāsakāḥ tathā
translated: just as by the knowledge of the five fires, so also those who meditate on symbols will go to the world of Brahman.

original: santi hi mano brahmetyupāsītetyādyāḥ pratīkaviṣayā vidyāḥ /
analyzed: santi hi manaḥ brahma iti upāsīta ityādyāḥ pratīka viṣayāḥ vidyāḥ
translated: There are indeed vidyās which have symbols as their objects, such as 'One should meditate that the mind is Brahman'.

original: tadvanto 'pyarcirādimārgeṇa kāryabrahmopāsakā iva gantumarhanti 'aniyamaḥ sarvāsām'ityaviśeṣeṇa vidyāntareṣvapi gateravadhāraṇāt /
analyzed: tadvantaḥ pi arciḥ ādi mārgeṇa kārya brahma upāsakāḥ iva gantum arhanti aniyamaḥ sarvāsām iti aviśeṣeṇa vidyā antareṣu api gateḥ avadhāraṇāt
translated: Those who possess them should go by the path of light etc., just as those who meditate on the Brahman that is the effect. 'There is no restriction for all' - because there is no distinction in other vidyās also, and because of the determination.

analyzed: na ca eṣām para brahma vidām iva gati asaṃbhavaḥ iti
translated: And for them, as for those who know the highest Brahman, there is no impossibility of going.

original: naca brahmakratava eva brahmalokabhājo nātatkratava ityapyekāntaḥ /
analyzed: na ca brahma kratavaḥ eva brahma loka bhājaḥ na a tad kratavaḥ iti api ekāntaḥ
translated: Nor is it true that only those who are intent on Brahman attain the world of Brahman, not those who are not so intent.

analyzed: a tad kratūnām api pañcāgni vidām tad prāpteḥ
translated: Because even those who are not intent on Brahman, but who know the five fires, attain that world.

original: na caite na brahmakratavo mano brahmetyupāsītetyādau sarvatra brahmānugamena tatkratutvasyāpi saṃbhavāt /
analyzed: na ca ete na brahma kratavaḥ manaḥ brahma iti upāsīta ityādau sarvatra brahma anugamena tad kratu tvasya api saṃbhavāt
translated: And they are not not intent on Brahman, because in all cases, such as 'One should meditate on the mind as Brahman,' the idea of Brahman is present, and so the state of being intent on Brahman is also possible.

analyzed: phala viśeṣasya brahma loka prāptau api upapatteḥ
translated: And because a particular result is possible even in the attainment of the world of Brahman.🔽Because that (world of Brahman) which has parts can be improved or diminished.

analyzed: tasya sāvayava tayā utkarṣa nikarṣa saṃbhavāt iti prāpte pratyucyate uttara uttara bhūyaḥ tvāt a brahmakratu bhāvataḥ
translated: To this we reply: Because of the increasing importance of the later (stages), and because of the absence of being intent on Brahman,

analyzed: pratīka upāsakān brahma lokam nāma anavaḥ nayet
translated: The non-Brahmin would lead the worshippers of the symbol to the world called Brahman.

analyzed: bhavatu pañcāgni vidyāyām abrahmakratūnām api brahma loka nayanam vacanāt
translated: Let it be that even those who are not intent on Brahman are led to the world of Brahman in the knowledge of the five fires, because of the statement.

original: kimiva hi vacanaṃ na kuryāt nāsti vacanasyātibhāra iha tu tadabhāvāt /
analyzed: kim iva hi vacanam na kuryāt na asti vacanasya atibhāraḥ iha tu tad abhāvāt
translated: For what indeed would a statement not do? There is no burden too heavy for a statement. But here that (statement) is absent.

original: 'taṃ yathāyathopāsate tadeva bhavati'iti śruterautsargikyānnāsati viśeṣavacane 'pavādo yujyate /
analyzed: tam yathā yathā upāsate tat eva bhavati iti śruteḥ autsargikyāt na asati viśeṣa vacane pa vādaḥ yujyate
translated: Because of the general Vedic statement 'Whatever one worships, that becomes just that for him,' an exception is not possible without a specific statement to the contrary.

analyzed: na ca pratīka upāsakaḥ brahma upāste sati api brahma iti anugame
translated: And the worshipper of the symbol does not worship Brahman, even though the word Brahman is used.

analyzed: kintu nāma ādi viśeṣam brahma rūpa tayā
translated: But he worships the particular name, etc. as Brahman.

analyzed: tathā khalu ayam nāma āditantraḥ na brahmatantraḥ
translated: Thus he is one whose beginning is name, etc., not one whose beginning is Brahman.

original: āśrayāntarapratyayasyāśrayāntare prakṣepaḥ pratīka iti hi vṛddhāḥ /
analyzed: āśraya antara pratyayasya āśraya antare prakṣepaḥ pratīkaḥ iti hi vṛddhāḥ
translated: The elders say that the symbol is the transference of the idea based on one substratum to another substratum.

original: brahmāśrayaśca pratyayo nāmādiṣu prakṣipta iti nāmatantraḥ /
analyzed: brahma āśrayaḥ ca pratyayaḥ nāma ādiṣu prakṣiptaḥ iti nāmatantraḥ
translated: And the idea based on Brahman is transferred to name, etc. Thus he is one whose beginning is name.

analyzed: tasmāt na tad upāsakaḥ brahmakratuḥ kintu nāma ādi kratuḥ
translated: Therefore, the worshipper of that is not one whose purpose is Brahman, but one whose purpose is name, etc.

analyzed: na ca brahma kratu tve nāma ādi upāsakānām aviśeṣāt uttarottara utkarṣaḥ saṃbhavī
translated: And when one's purpose is Brahman, the superiority of each subsequent stage is not possible due to the lack of distinction among the worshippers of name, etc.

analyzed: na ca brahmakratuḥ tad avayava kratuḥ yena tad avayava apekṣayā utkarṣaḥ varṇyeta
translated: And one whose purpose is Brahman is not one whose purpose is its parts, by which its superiority in relation to its parts could be described.

analyzed: tasmāt pratīka ālambanān viduṣaḥ varjayitvā sarvān anyān vikāra ālambanān nayati amānavaḥ brahma lokam
translated: Therefore, the non-human Brahman leads all other knowers to the world of Brahman, except those who have symbols as their objects.

original: na hyevamubhayathābhāva ubhayathārthatve kāṃścitpratīkālambanānna nayati vikāralambanānviduṣastu
analyzed: na hi evam ubhayathābhāvaḥ ubhayathārtha tve kāṃścid pratīka ālambanān na nayati vikāra lambanān viduṣaḥ tu
translated: For in this way, the existence in both ways does not lead some who have symbols as their objects, but it leads the knowers who have modifications as their objects.

analyzed: nayati iti abhyupagame kaścid doṣaḥ sti aniyamaḥ sarvāsām iti asya nyāyasya iti sarvam avadātam
translated: If you accept that it leads, what fault is there? This is the principle that there is no restriction for all. Thus everything is clear.

analyzed: na jātu gagana tad kusume niṣpadyete

analyzed: svarūpa avasthānam ced ātmanaḥ muktiḥ na sā niṣpadyeta
translated: And if the manifestation of the self is in its own form, liberation would not be produced.

analyzed: tasya gagana vat atyanta sataḥ prāk asattva abhāvāt

analyzed: na ca asya bandha abhāvaḥ niṣpadyate

analyzed: tasya tuccha svabhāvasya kārya tvena a tuccha tva prasaṅgāt

analyzed: bandhasya sat asat tvābhyām rūpam ekam viśiṣyate

translated: Therefore, Jaimini considered that the connection of mind, body and senses is invariably for those who possess power.

original: manaseti kevalamanoviṣayāṃ ca sa ekadhā bhavati tridhā bhavatīti śarīrendriyabhedaviṣayāṃ ca śrutimupalabhyāniyamavādī khalu bādarāyaṇo niyamavādau

analyzed: pūrvayoḥ na sahate

original: kāmeṣu hi ramaṇaṃ samanaskendriyeṇa śarīreṇa puruṣāṇāṃ siddhameveti nāsti śaṅkā manoyogasyeti tadvyavacchedo vyarthaḥ /
analyzed: kāmeṣu hi ramaṇam sa manaska indriyeṇa śarīreṇa puruṣāṇām siddham eva iti na asti śaṅkā manaḥ yogasya iti tad vyavacchedaḥ vyarthaḥ

analyzed: siddhasya tu manaḥ yogasya tad anya parisaṃkhyānena arthavat tvam avakalpate

analyzed: dvādaśa ahasya satra tvam āsana upāyi codane
translated: The twelve-day sacrifice is a session due to the injunction to sit and perform.

analyzed: ahīna tvam ca yajati codane sati gamyate

original: dvādaśāhamṛddhikāmā upeyurityupāyicodanena ya evaṃ vidvāṃsaḥ satramupayantīti ca dvādaśāhasya satratvaṃ bahukartṛkasya gamyate /

translated: Those desiring prosperity should undertake the twelve-day sacrifice, and those who know thus undertake the session - by this injunction to sit and perform, the twelve-day sacrifice is understood to be a session performed by many.

original: evaṃ tasyaiva dvādaśāhena prajākāmaṃ yājayediti yajaticodanena niyatakartṛparimāṇatvena dvirātreṇa yajatetyādivadahīnatvamapi gamyata iti /
analyzed: evam tasya eva dvādaśa ahena prajā kāmam yājayet iti yajati codanena niyata kartṛ parimāṇa tvena dvirātreṇa yajata ityādi vat ahīna tvam api gamyate iti
translated: Similarly, one should perform the sacrifice for one desiring offspring with that very twelve-day sacrifice - by this injunction to sacrifice, its non-inferiority is understood by the fixed number of performers, like in the statement one performs with the two-day sacrifice and so on.

original: saṃprati śarīrendriyābhāvena manomātreṇa viduṣaḥ svapnavatsūkṣmo bhogo bhavati /

analyzed: kutas upapatteḥ

analyzed: manasā etān iti śruteḥ
translated: From the Vedic text by the mind these.

analyzed: na ca sa śarīra vat upabhogaḥ śarīra ādi upādāna vaiyarthyāt

analyzed: sa śarīrasya tu puṣkalaḥ bhogaḥ

analyzed: iha api upapatteḥ iti anuṣañjanīyam  tat idam uktam sūtrābhyām tanu abhāve saṃdhya vat upapatteḥ

analyzed: bhāve jāgrat vat

analyzed: anādinā khalu antaḥkaraṇena autpattikena ayam avaruddhaḥ na idānīntanena antaḥkaraṇena upādhi tayā saṃbaddhum arhati
translated: For this (soul) is bound by the beginningless internal organ, not by the present internal organ as a limiting adjunct.

analyzed: tasmāt yathā dāruyantram tad prayoktrā cetanena adhiṣṭhitam sat tad icchām anurudhyate
translated: Therefore, just as a wooden machine, when controlled by an intelligent operator, conforms to his will,

original: evaṃ nirmāṇaśarīrāṇyapi sendriyāṇīti prāpte pratyabhidhīyateśarīratvaṃ na jātu syādbhogādhiṣṭhānatāṃ vinā /
analyzed: evam nirmāṇa śarīrāṇi api sa indriyāṇi iti prāpte pratyabhidhīyate śarīra tvam na jātu syāt bhoga adhiṣṭhāna tām vinā
translated: in the same way, the created bodies with senses are also so. This being the prima facie view, we reply: The state of being a body would never be possible without being the substratum of experience.

original: sa tridheti śarīratvamuktaṃ yuktaṃ ca tadvibhau //
analyzed: sa tridhā iti śarīra tvam uktam yuktam ca tat vibhau
translated: That (soul) is threefold, and the state of being a body is said to be proper for that all-pervading one.

original: sa tridhā bhavati pañcadhā saptadhā navadhetyādikā śrutirviduṣo nānābhāvamācakṣāṇā bhinnaśarīrendriyopādhisaṃbandhe 'vakalpate nādehahetubhūtabhede
analyzed: sa tridhā bhavati pañcadhā saptadhā navadhā ityādikā śrutiḥ viduṣaḥ nānābhāvam ācakṣāṇā bhinna śarīra indriya upādhi saṃbandhe na a deha hetu bhūta bhede
translated: The Vedic texts beginning with It is threefold, fivefold, sevenfold, ninefold... describe the different states of the learned one, and are possible in the connection with different bodies and sense organs as limiting adjuncts, not in the difference of the primordial material cause of the body.

original: nahi yantrāṇi bhinnāni nirmāya vāhayanyantravāho nānātvenāpadiśyate /
analyzed: nahi yantrāṇi bhinnāni nirmāya vāhayan yantra vāhaḥ nānātvena apadiśyate
translated: For when different machines are created and operated by a machine operator, he is not referred to as different.

original: bhogādhiṣṭhānatvaṃ ca śarīratvaṃ nābhogādhiṣṭhāneṣu yantreṣviva yujyate /
analyzed: bhoga adhiṣṭhāna tvam ca śarīra tvam na a bhoga adhiṣṭhāneṣu yantreṣu iva yujyate
translated: And the state of being a body is the state of being the substratum of experience, which is not possible in the case of machines, which are not the substratum of experience.

analyzed: tasmāt deha antarāṇi sṛjati
translated: Therefore, he creates other bodies.

analyzed: na vā anena adhiṣṭhitāni deha pakṣe vartante
translated: Or, they do not exist as bodies without being controlled by him.

original: naca sarvagatasya vastuto vigalitaprāyāvidyasya viduṣaḥ pṛthagjanasyevautpattikāntaḥkaraṇavaśyatā yena tadautpattikamantaḥkaraṇamāgantukāntaḥkaraṇāntarasaṃbandhamasya 🔽vārayet /
analyzed: na ca sarvagatasya vastutas vigalita prāya avidyasya viduṣaḥ pṛthagjanasya iva autpattika antaḥkaraṇa vaśya tā yena tat autpattikam antaḥkaraṇam āgantuka antaḥkaraṇa antara saṃbandham asya  / vārayet
translated: And for the knower, who is all-pervading and has almost completely shed ignorance, there is no natural dependence on the internal organ, as there is for an ordinary person, by which that natural internal organ would prevent the connection of another adventitious internal organ with him.

original: tasmādvidvān sarvasya vaśī sarveśvaraḥ satyasaṃkalpaḥ sendriyamanāṃsi śarīrāṇi nirmāya tāni caikapade praviśya tattadindriyamantaḥkaraṇaisteṣu
analyzed: tasmāt vidvān sarvasya vaśī sarva īśvaraḥ satya saṃkalpaḥ sa indriya manāṃsi śarīrāṇi nirmāya tāni ca eka pade praviśya tat tat indriyam antaḥkaraṇaiḥ teṣu
translated: Therefore, it is proper that the knower, being the master of all, the lord of all, with true resolve, creates bodies with sense organs and minds, and entering them at once,

analyzed: lokeṣu muktaḥ viharati iti sāṃpratam
translated: he dwells liberated in those worlds through those various sense organs and internal organs.

original: pradīpavaditi tu nidarśanaṃ pradīpaikyaṃ pradīpavyaktiṣūpacaryate bhinnavartivartinīnāṃ bhinnavyaktīnāṃ bhedāt /
analyzed: pradīpa vat iti tu nidarśanam pradīpa aikyam pradīpa vyaktiṣu upacaryate bhinna varti vartinīnām bhinna vyaktīnām bhedāt
translated: But the example of the lamp is used, where the unity of the lamp is figuratively applied to the individual lamps, because of the difference between the individual lamps burning in different wicks.

analyzed: evam vidvān jīvātmā dehabhede pi ekaḥ iti parāmarśa arthaḥ
translated: Similarly, the individual soul is one even in the difference of bodies, this is the meaning of the reflection.

analyzed: eka manaḥ nuvartīn iti eka abhiprāya vartīni iti arthaḥ
translated: One who follows the same mind means one who follows the same intention.

analyzed: saṃpannaḥ kevalaḥ muktaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is said to be complete, solitary, and liberated.

analyzed: na ca etasya itthaṃbhāva saṃbhavaḥ śruti virodhāt iti uktam artha jātam ākṣipati katham punar muktasya iti
translated: And this state of being is not possible for him, because of the contradiction with the scriptures. Thus the group of meanings stated is disputed with the question How then is it for the liberated one?

analyzed: salile iti
translated: Like water.

analyzed: salilam iva salilaḥ salila prātipadikāt sarva prātipadikebhyaḥ iti upamānāt ācāre kvipi kṛte paca ādi a ci ca kṛte rūpam
translated: It is like water, it is watery. From the nominal stem salila (water), it is the form of all nominal stems, from the comparison, when the kvip affix is formed, and the a suffix of the pac class is added.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavatiyathā salilamambhonidhau prakṣiptaṃ tadekībhāvamupayāti /🔽evaṃ draṣṭāpi brahmaṇeti /

translated: This is what is said: Just as water, when thrown into the ocean, becomes of the same nature as it,

analyzed: start
translated: so also the seer becomes of the same nature as Brahman.

analyzed: atra uttaram sūtram
translated: Here is the reply in the sutra:

analyzed: sva apyaya saṃpattyoḥ anyatara apekṣam āviṣkṛtam hi
translated: It is revealed with reference to either sleep or attainment.

original: āsu kāścicchrutayaḥ suṣuptimapekṣya kāścittu saṃpattiṃ tadadhikārāt /
analyzed: āsu kāścid śrutayaḥ suṣuptim apekṣya kāścid tu saṃpattim tad adhikārāt
translated: Among them, some scriptures refer to deep sleep, while some refer to attainment, because that is the topic.

original: aiśvaryaśrutayastu saguṇavidyāvipākāvasthāpekṣā muktyabhisaṃdhānaṃ tu tadavasthāsatteryathāruṇadarśane saṃdhyāyāṃ divasābhidhānam ////🔽START / / /
analyzed: aiśvarya śrutayaḥ tu sa guṇa vidyā vipāka avasthā apekṣāḥ mukti abhisaṃdhānam tu tad avasthā āsatteḥ yathā aruṇa darśane saṃdhyāyām divasa abhidhānam 🔽start
translated: But the scriptures on lordship refer to the state of the fruition of knowledge with qualities. The designation of liberation is like calling the evening day when the dawn is seen, because of the existence of that state.

analyzed: jagat vyāpāra varjam prakaraṇāt asaṃnihita tvāt ca  svārājya kāmacāra ādi śrutibhyaḥ syāt niraṅkuśaḥ
translated: Because of the absence of any mention of the world's operations in the context, and because of the absence of any mention of them, ...🔽The one who is free from all restraints is indicated by the scriptures speaking of self-sovereignty, acting as one wishes, etc.

analyzed: sva kārye īśvara adhīna siddhiḥ api atra sādhakaḥ
translated: The fact that even his success is dependent on God is a proof in this matter.

original: 'āpnoti svārājyaṃ' 'sarve 'smai devā balimāvahanti' 'sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāro bhavati'ityādiśrutibhyo viduṣaḥ parabrahmaṇa ivānyānadhīnatvamaiśvaryamavagamyate
analyzed: āpnoti svārājyam sarve smai devāḥ balim āvahanti sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati ityādi śrutibhyaḥ viduṣaḥ para brahmaṇaḥ iva anya anadhīna tvam aiśvaryam avagamyate
translated: From the scriptures such as He attains self-sovereignty, All the gods bring him offerings, He becomes free to act as he wishes in all the worlds, it is understood that the knower has sovereignty independent of others, like the supreme Brahman.

original: nanvasya brahmopāsanālabdhamaiśvaryaṃ kathaṃ brahmādhīnaṃ na tu svabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nanu asya brahma upāsanā labdham aiśvaryam katham brahma adhīnam na tu svabhāvaḥ
translated: How can his sovereignty obtained through meditation on Brahman be dependent on Brahman, and not natural?

analyzed: nahi kāraṇa adhīna janmānaḥ bhāvāḥ sva kārye sva kāraṇam apekṣante
translated: For entities whose birth is dependent on causes do not depend on their causes in their own effects.

analyzed: kim tu atra te svatantrāḥ eva
translated: Rather, they are independent in this matter.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ mṛd piṇḍa daṇḍa cakra ādi ghaṭaḥ janmani apekṣate
translated: As they say: The pot depends on the lump of clay, the stick, the wheel, etc. at the time of its birth.

analyzed: udaka āharaṇe tu asya tad apekṣā na vidyate
translated: But in the matter of carrying water, it does not depend on them.

original: na ca viduṣāṃ parameśvarādhīnaiśvaryasiddhitvāttadgatamaiśvaryaṃ yena laukikā iva rājāno mahārājādhīnaḥ svavyāpāre vidvāṃsaḥ parameśvarādhīnā
analyzed: na ca viduṣām parameśvara adhīna aiśvarya siddhi tvāt tad gatam aiśvaryam yena laukikāḥ iva rājānaḥ mahārāja adhīnaḥ sva vyāpāre vidvāṃsaḥ parameśvara adhīnā
translated: And the wise are not dependent on the Supreme Lord for the attainment of their power, by which power they would be like worldly kings, dependent on a great king in their own affairs.

analyzed: bhaveyuḥ
translated: They are not dependent on the Supreme Lord.

original: na khalu yadadhīnotpādaṃ yasya rūpaṃ tattadrūpādūnaṃ bhavatīti kaścinniyamaḥ /
analyzed: na khalu yad adhīna utpādam yasya rūpam tat tat rūpāt ūnam bhavati iti kaścid niyamaḥ
translated: For there is no rule that what is produced dependent on something else is less than that.

original: tatsamānāṃ tadadhikānāṃ ca darśanāttathā hyantevāsī gurvadhīnavidhaḥ tatsamastadadhiko vā dṛśyate /
analyzed: tad samānām tad adhikānām ca darśanāt tathā hi antevāsī guru adhīna vidhaḥ tad samaḥ tad adhikaḥ vā dṛśyate
translated: Because they are seen to be equal to it or superior to it. For example, a pupil, dependent on the teacher for his livelihood, is seen to be equal to him or superior to him.

analyzed: duṣṭa sāmantāḥ ca pārthiva adhīna aiśvaryāḥ pārthivān spardhamānāḥ tān vijayamānāḥ vā dṛśyante
translated: And wicked feudatories, whose power is dependent on the king, are seen to rival the king or to conquer him.

original: tadiha niratiśayaiśvaryatvāt parameśvarasya mā nāma bhūvanvidvāṃsastato 'dhikāstatsamāstu bhaviṣyanti /
analyzed: tat iha niratiśaya aiśvarya tvāt parameśvarasya mā nāma bhūvan vidvāṃsaḥ tatas dhikāḥ tad samāḥ tu bhaviṣyanti
translated: Therefore, here, since the Supreme Lord has unsurpassed power, let the wise not be greater than him, but let them be equal to him.

analyzed: tathā ca na tad adhīnāḥ
translated: And thus they are not dependent on him.

analyzed: nahi sama pradhāna bhāvānām asti mithas upekṣā
translated: For those who are equal in importance have no mutual dependence.

original: tadete svatantrāḥ santastadvyāpāre jagatsarjane 'pi pravarteranniti prāpte pratyabhidhīyatenityatvādanapekṣatvāt śrutestatprakramādapi /🔽ekyamatyācca viduṣāṃ parameśvaratantratā //
analyzed: tat ete svatantrāḥ santaḥ tad vyāpāre jagat sarjane pi pravarteran iti prāpte pratyabhidhīyate nitya tvāt anapekṣa tvāt śruteḥ tad prakramāt api  ekya matyāt ca viduṣām parameśvara tantra tā
translated: and because of the agreement of the learned, the creation of the world is dependent on the Supreme Lord.

original: jagatsargalakṣaṇaṃ hi kāryaṃ kāraṇaikasvabhāvasyaiva hi bhavatu āho kāryakāraṇasvabhāvasya /
analyzed: jagat sarga lakṣaṇam hi kāryam kāraṇa eka svabhāvasya eva hi bhavatu āho kārya kāraṇa svabhāvasya
translated: For the effect characterized by the creation of the world can belong either to something having the nature of only the cause, or to something having the nature of both effect and cause.

original: tatrobhayasvabhāvasya svotpattau mūlakāraṇāpekṣasya pūrvasiddhaḥ parameśvara eva kāraṇamabhyupetavya iti sa evaiko 'stu jagatkāraṇam /
analyzed: tatra ubhaya svabhāvasya sva utpattau mūla kāraṇa apekṣasya pūrva siddhaḥ parameśvaraḥ eva kāraṇam abhyupetavyaḥ iti saḥ eva ekaḥ stu jagat kāraṇam
translated: If it belongs to something having both natures, which is dependent on a primary cause for its own origination, then the previously established Supreme Lord alone must be accepted as the cause. Thus He alone should be the cause of the world.

analyzed: tasya eva nitya tvena sva kāraṇa anapekṣasya kḷpta sāmarthyāt
translated: For He alone is eternal, independent of His own cause, and has established power.

analyzed: kalpya sāmarthyāḥ tu jagat sarjanam prati vidvāṃsaḥ
translated: But those who know how to create the world have power that must be imagined.

analyzed: na ca jagat sraṣṭṛ tvam eṣām śrūyate
translated: And their status as creators of the world is not heard.

analyzed: śrūyate tu atrabhavataḥ parameśvarasya eva
translated: But it is heard only of the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: tam eva prakṛtya sarvāsām tad śrutīnām pravṛtteḥ
translated: For all those scriptural statements occur with reference to Him alone.

original: apica samapradhānānāṃ hi na niyamavadaikamatyaṃ dṛṣṭamiti yadaikaḥ sisṛkṣati tadaivetaraḥ saṃjihīrṣatītyaparyāyeṇa sṛṣṭisaṃhārau syātām /
analyzed: apica sama pradhānānām hi na niyamavat aikamatyam dṛṣṭam iti yadā ekaḥ sisṛkṣati tadā eva itaraḥ saṃjihīrṣati iti aparyāyeṇa sṛṣṭi saṃhārau syātām
translated: Moreover, it is seen that there is no unanimity in the case of co-ordinate things. Therefore, when one desires to create, the other desires to destroy. Thus creation and destruction would occur alternately.

analyzed: na ca ubhayoḥ api īśvara tvam vyāghātam
translated: And the lordship of both is not contradictory.

original: ekasya tu tadādhipatye tadabhiprāyānurodhināṃ sarveṣāmaikamatyopapatteradoṣaḥ /🔽tatrāgantukānāṃ kāraṇādhīnajanmaiśvaryāṇāṃ gṛhyamāṇaviśeṣatayāsamatvānnityaiśvaryaśālinaḥ

translated: But when one is the lord, it is proper that all others, who are in accordance with His will, should be unanimous. So there is no fault.🔽Among them, the accidental lordships, which are born dependent on causes, are not equal because they are grasped as having distinctions. He alone is the supreme lord of those who possess eternal lordship.

original: sa eva teṣāmadhīśa iti tattantrā vidvāṃsa iti parameśvaravyāpārasya sargasaṃhārasya neśate // //

translated: Therefore, the wise ones are dependent on Him. Thus they are not able to control the activity of the Supreme Lord, which is creation and destruction.
